The Silver Peal Ringers

Who are We?

The Silver Peal Ringers are a dedicated ensemble of church bellringers who journey across the country sharing the rich heritage of English change ringing. Blending tradition with showmanship, they bring to life the resonant music of handbells and tower bells in churches, festivals, and community events nationwide. With precision, teamwork, and a deep love for their craft, the group transforms each performance into a vibrant celebration of sound, history, and fellowship.

Founded in 1978 by a small circle of tower ringers from three neighbouring parishes, the group began as a modest effort to rekindle interest in bellringing among younger generations. Their first performances were informal—community fêtes, church anniversaries, and charity fundraisers—but their warm camaraderie and crisp, musical ringing soon earned them invitations across the country.

By the early 1990s, the ensemble had developed a full touring repertoire featuring handbell arrangements, ringing demonstrations, and educational workshops. As their reputation grew, so did their involvement in national commemorations. In 2018, The Silver Peal Ringers were honoured to take part in special peals and half-muffled ringing to mark the Centenary of the End of World War I, joining bell towers nationwide in paying tribute to the fallen. Two years later, in 2020, they again took to the road—where permitted—to help commemorate the 75th Anniversary of the End of World War II, offering uplifting performances that celebrated peace and remembered sacrifice.

Over the decades, they have visited hundreds of towers across the UK, forging friendships with local bands, supporting restoration projects, and helping keep alive methods that have echoed through English history for centuries. Today, The Silver Peal Ringers remain committed to their founding mission: to inspire, to teach, and to let the timeless art of bellringing resonate wherever their travels take them.
